passages.text: - 2Q GDP delivered expected weakness- The trade war pummeled exports and capex, but household consumption picked up last quarter- We look for a stall in employment in next week's LFS, with the unemployment rate jumping to \(7.1\%\)

While the Bank of Canada has remained on hold for three consecutive meetings while waiting for more information about the impact of tariffs on growth and inflation, Governor Tiff Macklem has signaled that the Governing Council would consider cutting rates if the economy continues to show signs of weakness and upward price pressures from trade disruptions remain contained. Today's 2Q GDP report delivered on expectations for further evidence of a weaker economy, with overall activity contracting \(1.6\% \mathrm{q} / \mathrm{q}\) , saar. The boost from the front- loading of exports to get ahead of tariffs, which kept overall activity robust at the start of the year, reversed sharply in 2Q and business fixed investment contracted amidst persistent uncertainty over trade policy. Both exports and business equipment investment posted the steepest declines of the post- pandemic period last quarter.

Sectors with less direct exposure to the trade conflict, however, look to have remained relatively unscathed. A strong rebound in household consumption, which expanded \(4.5\%\) ar in 2Q, suggests the trade war's impact hadn't fully permeated the broader economy last quarter (Figure 1). While we believe that some of this apparent strength is attributable to the tail- end of front- loaded spending ahead of anticipated tariff- related price hikes, the pickup in spending was evenly distributed between goods and services in 2Q. The Bank of Canada's Survey on Business Conditions for 3Q released earlier this week suggests that a large share of firms have been delaying passing on tariff costs to consumers.
Figure 1: Canada real GDP
The second condition needed for the Governing Council to support additional rate cuts is more reassurance that inflation broadly remains on a downward trajectory. Here the latest

news is also dovish. While counter- tariffs on autos, steel, and aluminum remain in place, Canada removed its other retaliatory levies on imports from the US last week following a call between PM Carney and US president Trump. This should reduce upward pressure on inflation from trade disruptions. The average of the Bank of Canada's core components (median, trimmed mean) has been stuck above the top of the \(3\%\) inflation target band, but Governor Macklem has recently argued that underlying inflation is running around \(2.5\%\) . While the next review of the Bank's mandate is not due until 2026, Governor Macklem hinted that the Bank is weighing changes to how it assesses core inflation in prepared remarks delivered at a Bank of Mexico event earlier this week.

We think it will take weakness spreading beyond sectors directly exposed to tariffs later this year to deliver the mild recession and 75bp of additional policy rate easing by the BoC we have in our forecast. The manufacturing sector has been hit hard by the trade war shock, but only accounts for \(9\%\) of Canada's economy. That said, indications of lingering labor market weakness in the August Labour Force Survey and a well behaved core CPI in August could be enough to tip the balance in favor of a rate cut in September.

We will be keenly watching next week's Labour Force Survey for signs of job losses extending beyond sectors directly affected by the tariffs. Our forecast is for a stall in employment and a two- tenths rise in the unemployment rate to \(7.1\%\) . The six- month average of monthly job gains fell to its lowest level in over four years in July (Figure 2). A flat August print would bring this smoothed measure of employment growth to a new low of \(4.3\mathrm{k}\) . We estimate average hourly earnings softened \(0.3\% - \mathrm{pt}\) to \(3.2\%\) a year in August. We see the unemployment rate rising to \(7.4\%\) by year- end despite some downward pressure on labor force growth due to less generous immigration policies.
Figure 2: Labour Force Survey employment
Week of September 1- 5
ThuInternational tradeSep 4Sa8:30amAprMayJunJulBalance (C$ bn)-7.64-5.49-5.86-4.26Exports (%m/m)-11.32.00.92.7Imports (%m/m)-3.2-1.41.40.1Real balance-8.23-6.52-7.84

We project that Canada's nominal merchandise trade deficit narrowed to C\$4.26bn in July from C\$5.86bn in June. The nominal merchandise trade balance widened somewhat in June, the fourth month with President Trump's tariffs in place. We think nominal exports perked up \(2.7\%\) in July, while imports moved sideways last month. Solid growth in exports last month puts net trade on track to boost growth this quarter after subtracting \(8.1\%\) - pt in 2Q.
FriIvey PMISep 510:00amMayJunJulAugComposite index¹ (sa)51.852.251.451.1Purchasing index (sa)48.953.355.854.21. Calculated and seasonally adjusted by J.P. Morgan

We forecast a 1.6pt decline in the seasonally adjusted Ivey PMI to 54.2 in August. We expect our derived composite index to step down to 51.1. The Ivey PMI rose a further 2.5pt to 54.2 in July, but we think that the continued strain from tariffs will see the index moderate in August.
Fri Labor force survey

We predict that hiring stalled in August after the economy sheet 41k jobs in July. Despite the pullback in employment growth in July's Labour Force Survey, a shrinking labor force kept the unemployment rate unchanged \(6.9\%\) . We think that the labor market will continue to lose steam gradually if uncertainties around disruptive US policies persist. While USMCA exemptions have kept the average effective tariff rate on US imports from Canada around \(5\%\) , the direction of travel for US tariffs on Canadian goods appears upward. A rebound in the labor force should lift the unemployment rate
to a nearly four- year high of \(7.1\%\) in August. We also look for hours worked to rise last month. We estimate average hourly earnings moderated \(0.3\%\) - pt to \(3.2\%\) oya in August.
Current account (Aug 28) C\$ bn, saqr, unless noted

Canada's current account deficit widened to a record C\$21.2bn in 2Q25 from C\$1.3bn in 1Q25. The goods and services deficit increased to C\$19.5bn last quarter. Both exports and imports fell back last quarter against the backdrop of an escalating trade war with the US. The goods deficit surged to a record C\$19.5bn last quarter.
Quarterly GDP (Aug 29)

Real GDP contracted \(1.6\% q / q\) , saar in 2Q25. This marked a sharp downshift from 1Q's strong \(2.0\%\) outturn. Following the boost in 1Q activity from the pull- forward of demand for exports ahead of tariff hikes, the reversal of this front- loading impulse pushed growth into negative territory last quarter. Net trade was an \(8.1\%\) - pt drag on growth in 2Q. Strong \(4.5\%\) ar growth in PCE suggests that the broader economy has not yet fully felt the brunt of the trade war.
Monthly GDP (Aug 29)

Monthly GDP unexpectedly fell \(0.1\%\) in June after an earlier flash estimate suggested a return to growth at the close of 2Q. This result marked a third consecutive month of declining activity. A \(0.5\%\) contraction in the goods- producing industries offset \(0.1\%\) growth in the services sector in June. Statistics Canada's July advance estimate indicated that strength in real estate, mining, and wholesale trade offset weakness in retail trade to lift overall activity \(0.1\%\) last month.
Sources: Statistics Canada, Ivey Business School, CMHC, S&P Global, Teranet/National Bank of Canada, CREA, CFIB, Bank of Canada, J.P. Morgan forecasts
